level1.label: Level 1
level1.summary: Your digestion is working — but it's working under load. This pattern tends to show up when demand exceeds what your system can comfortably respond to, so symptoms fluctuate with context rather than staying constant.
keyPatterns: Symptoms that come and go rather than persist
More reactive digestion during stress, irregular eating, travel, or long stretches of pushing through
Energy dips that aren't constant, but are familiar
firstFocusAreas: Recognize this as a capacity pattern (not a failure)
Notice which contexts increase load (stress, rhythm, disruption)
Reduce noise: avoid changing too many inputs at once
level1.methodPositioning: Generic gut advice assumes the same inputs produce the same outcomes for everyone. But context-sensitive patterns shift with conditions, which is why blanket solutions often don't stick. Fine Diet starts by naming the pattern and learning what stabilizes it over time — framework first, not prescriptions.

email.subject: Your Gut Check results — a clearer picture
email.preheader: What your digestion is responding to right now

page1.headline: Your digestion is working — but it's working under load.
body: What we're seeing in your answers isn't a breakdown. It's a pattern that tends to show up when the digestive system is carrying more demand than it can comfortably respond to.

People with this pattern often notice that their digestion feels mostly fine — until it isn't. Symptoms come and go. Energy dips aren't constant, but they're familiar. Discomfort shows up in response to stress, irregular eating, travel, or long stretches of "pushing through."
Nothing here points to something being fundamentally wrong. What it suggests is sensitivity to context.
When your system has enough support — time, rhythm, consistency — it adapts well. When that support erodes, digestion becomes more reactive.
This isn't random. It's your system signaling where its current limits are.
snapshotBullets: Digestive symptoms that fluctuate rather than persist
Energy that drops under stress or schedule changes
A sense that small disruptions have outsized effects
page1.snapshotCloser: These signals don't mean fragility. They point to responsiveness.

page2.headline: This pattern is shaped by load, not by willpower.
body: For this pattern, digestive discomfort usually isn't caused by a single food or habit. It's more often the accumulation of factors that quietly tax the system over time.

Stress doesn't just affect the mind — it changes how the gut responds. Irregular meals don't just "throw things off" — they reduce the system's ability to anticipate and adapt. Even positive changes, introduced too quickly, can feel destabilizing.
When too many inputs shift at once, the digestive system doesn't fail — it prioritizes. And digestion is often what gets deprioritized first.
That's why advice that focuses on effort or discipline tends to miss the mark for this pattern. The issue isn't motivation. It's capacity.
reframeBody: Rather than asking, "What should I be doing better?" this pattern responds more to the question:
"What is my system being asked to carry right now?"
Understanding that difference is where real clarity begins.

page3.headline: Most gut advice ignores patterns like this.
body: Generic digestive advice assumes that the same inputs produce the same outcomes for everyone. But patterns like yours don't work that way.

When digestion is context-sensitive, blanket solutions often create more noise than clarity. One week something "works," the next week it doesn't — not because you did anything wrong, but because the conditions changed.
This is where many people get stuck: trying to fix symptoms instead of understanding signals; chasing consistency through control rather than alignment; interpreting fluctuation as failure.
The Fine Diet Method was built around a different starting point.
Instead of asking, "What should I add or remove?" it begins with, "What pattern is present — and what does it need to stabilize over time?"
That distinction matters. And it's the foundation for making changes that actually hold.
closingBody: This result isn't a verdict. It's a snapshot.
It shows how your digestion is currently responding to the demands placed on it — and it gives us a shared language to understand that response more clearly going forward.
When you're ready, the next step isn't doing more. It's learning how to work with this pattern, rather than around it.

level2.label: Sensitive
level2.summary: Your gut health shows sensitivity patterns. You experience occasional digestive discomfort that responds to dietary and lifestyle adjustments.
level2.methodPositioning: Learn how The Fine Diet Method can help you identify patterns and create a personalized approach to support your sensitive gut.
